title: Rotational inertia rank - 3 disks different axes

content.question: The figure shows three uniform disks, each with the same mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> but having different radii, that are each free to rotate about axes directed out of the plane of the figure. Disk <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> has radius <math alttext="r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and is connected by a rod of negligible mass to a point on a rotation axis that is a distance <math alttext="3 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the disk’s center. Disk <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> has radius <math alttext="2 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and can rotate about an axis at the top edge of the disk. Disk <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext></math> has radius <math alttext="4 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and can rotate about an axis through its center. The rotational inertia about the center of mass for any uniform disk of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> is <math alttext="I equals one half m r squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Rank the disks’ rotational inertias <math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>, and <math alttext="I sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></math> about their respective rotation axes.
